channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Preparing to Meet Trump, Mexican Leader Seeks Common Ground
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico seemed to adapt President Trump’s “America first” message to his own purposes in a speech on Monday.
item.description: President Enrique Peña Nieto promised a robust dialogue with President Trump at their meeting next week, with the protection of Mexican citizens a priority.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Trump Revives Ban on Foreign Aid to Groups That Give Abortion Counseling
item.media:description: President Trump signed a memorandum Monday, one of his first orders as president, freezing federal funding to health providers abroad who discuss abortion as a family-planning option.
item.description: Anti-abortion groups welcomed President Trump’s decision, while reproductive rights advocates said it would endanger women in poor countries by reducing health services.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Killing of a Young Woman Grips Iceland
item.media:description: The disappearance of Birna Brjansdottir dominated news bulletins across Iceland and about 775 rescue workers volunteered to search for her.
item.description: A nation where killings are rare was transfixed by the mystery of a young woman’s disappearance and shaken when her body turned up on a beach.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and EGILL BJARNASON

item.title: German Party Won’t Expel Rightist Who Assailed Holocaust Apology
item.media:description: Björn Höcke, a regional leader of the Alternative for Germany party, in 2015.
item.description: The decision by the Alternative for Germany to only discipline Björn Höcke leaves him open to attract more sympathizers.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: First Day of Syria Peace Talks Quickly Descends Into Quarreling
item.media:description: Syrian peace negotiators had heated exchanges during talks in a hotel in Astana, Kazakhstan, on Monday, the first day of meetings to try to end the Syrian civil war.
item.description: The talks between rebels and the Syrian government, arranged by Turkey and Russia, were marked by accusations and harsh words on both sides.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Trump Presidency Is Already Altering Israeli-Palestinian Politics
item.media:description: Speculation swirled that the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv might move to Jerusalem.
item.description: The transition, and questions surrounding it, rippled through issues including the location of the American Embassy and whether Palestinians are on the edge of a renewed revolt.
item.dc:creator: IAN FISHER

item.title: Quandary in South Sudan: Should It Lose Its Hard-Won Independence?
item.media:description: A camp for tens of thousands of internally displaced people on the outskirts of Juba, South Sudan, in 2016.
item.description: The five-year-old country is in woeful straits as a civil war drags on. But a proposal to create a trusteeship of outside powers is meeting resistance.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: As Gambia’s Yahya Jammeh Entered Exile, Plane Stuffed With Riches Followed
item.media:description: Gambian soldiers guarded the presidential palace in Banjul, the capital, on Monday.
item.description: Mr. Jammeh left with two Rolls-Royces, a Mercedes-Benz, and other cars and luxury items, according to an airport official and a diplomat familiar with activities in the country.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Datang Journal: In China, an Ancient People Watch Their Floating Life Dissolve
item.media:description: Residents of this floating village in Datang are members of the Tanka group, an ancient people scattered across southern China who have survived on coastal waterways.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Members of the Tanka group in southern China have survived on coastal waterways, and on the margins of society. As cities spread, their way of life is disappearing.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and ADAM WU

item.title: Readers in India Reflect on Coping With Miserable 2016 Heat
item.media:description: People cooled off in a fountain during a sweltering heat wave last May in New Delhi.
item.description: In May, as the Earth was going through what ended up being its hottest year on record, the western and northern parts of India experienced a brutal heat wave.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 3 Performances by Sumi Jo, Korean Soprano, Canceled in China
item.media:description: The South Korean soprano Sumi Jo during a gala concert in Tokyo in 2015.
item.description: The unexplained cancellations have heightened suspicions that South Korean classical musicians are the latest casualties of political tensions with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: What in the World: For a Modest Price, the Streets of Paris Can Be Yours
item.media:description: Some Paris streets still have visible cobblestone paving, but on many the stones have been buried under asphalt and are often torn up during construction. Rather than dump them, the city has started to salvage and sell the stones.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Cobblestones have lined Paris’s streets since the 12th century. When the city began selling used ones, an entrepreneur saw a chance to make unique souvenirs.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Swedish Police Investigate Report of Rape on Facebook Live
item.description: The Swedish authorities arrested three men on suspicion of rape and urged people with access to images showing the episode to make them available to the police.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: Global Health: Malnutrition Wiping Out Children in Northern Nigeria, Aid Workers Say
item.media:description: Women and their children at a feeding center run by M.S. F. in Nigeria in August.
item.description: Medical workers have seen few infants and toddlers in refugee camps in Nigeria’s Borno State and fear that many have died of starvation and related diseases.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Panama to Allow Ex-Dictator Noriega House Arrest, Says Lawyer
item.description: A lawyer for Panama's jailed ex-dictator Manuel Noriega says a court has granted him house arrest so he can prepare for brain surgery.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Trilobites: A Pioneering Woman of Science Re-Emerges After 300 Years
item.media:description: Maria Sibylla Merian, a German-born woman living in the Netherlands, had a successful career as an artist, botanist, naturalist and entomologist.
item.media:credit: Jacob Houbraken, after Georg Gsell, via Metamorphosis insectorum Surinamensium, Amsterdam 1705, The Hague, National Library of the Netherlands
item.description: Maria Sibylla Merian captivated Europeans with her studies of insects, only to later have her work largely dismissed. Now, her findings are being celebrated again.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: Protests Over Bull Riding Turn Violent in India
item.media:description: Protesters against the ban of jallikattu, a traditional bull-taming sport, tried to form a human chain as they faced the police in Chennai, India, on Monday.
item.description: The traditional sport of jallikattu was banned by the Supreme Court for animal cruelty, leading to protests over a loss of cultural identity.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Why a Trident Missile Test Is Rocking British Politics
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain at a regional cabinet meeting on Monday in Runcorn, England.
item.description: Critics are accusing the British government of covering up a failed test as it pushed new spending on nuclear submarines. Here is what the controversy is all about.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA and PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: South Korean Minister Credits Junior Officials With Exposing Artist Blacklist
item.media:description: Yoo Jin-ryong, a former culture minister, said on Monday that many rank-and-file officials felt “abused” and “humiliated” when President Park Geun-hye’s office ordered them not to fund artists deemed hostile.
item.description: Culture Ministry workers gathered information for the authorities after being told not to fund artists deemed unfriendly to the president, a former official said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Japanese Panel Signals Support for One-Time Law to Let Emperor Abdicate
item.media:description: Emperor Akihito of Japan, right, receiving a document before his opening address to Parliament this month. The governing party is expected to propose an abdication measure in April that would apply only to him.
item.description: A government-appointed panel tacitly recommended that a special provision, rather than more permanent changes, would be preferable.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: To Secular Bangladeshis, Textbook Changes Are a Harbinger
item.media:description: Students at a madrasa, or Islamic school, last year in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Changes were recently made to textbooks after requests from conservative Islamic religious scholars.
item.description: Revisions sought by Islamic scholars were barely noticeable to the public, but intellectuals see them as government accommodation of a larger shift toward radical Islam.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: Oil Producers Claim Progress in Curbing the World’s Daily Supply
item.description: A group of OPEC and non-OPEC oil producers have joined forces to reduce the daily amount of oil on sale by 1.8 million barrels in the first six months of this year.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: 75 Arrested in European Crackdown on Art Trafficking
item.description: The European police recovered about 3,500 stolen archaeological artifacts and other artworks, Spain’s Interior Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Renewed Fighting and Drone Strikes in Yemen Kill About 75
item.media:description: An airstrike by the Saudi-led coalition hit an army base in Sana, Yemen, on Sunday.
item.description: Airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition killed more than 50 Houthi rebels, and two suspected U.S. drone attacks killed 10 militants with Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: ‘Gambia Is Back Again,’ but Its New Leader Is Still in Senegal
item.media:description: A ferry carrying people who fled Gambia arrived back in the country after the former president, Yahya Jammeh, relinquished power on Saturday.
item.description: President Adama Barrow has been in the neighboring nation for a week. The incumbent he defeated, Yahya Jammeh, had refused to step down until Saturday.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Cubans Newly Blocked at U.S. Border Place Hopes in Trump
item.media:description: Yamila González Cabeza, 44, center, helped to organize clothes donated for fellow Cubans stuck at the border.
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.description: The Obama administration ended special immigration privileges for Cubans after normalizing relations with Cuba. Now migrants arrive into a desperate limbo after an arduous journey.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Lanzarote Journal: Undersea Museum Keeps Fish Feeding and Its Social Commentary Biting
item.media:description: Jason deCaires Taylor, a British sculptor, outside his studio in Lanzarote, Spain. They are bes
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: An installation of 300 statues off a Spanish island forms an artificial reef and addresses issues like Europe’s migration crisis, and the destruction of ocean reefs.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: 7 Questions for Gambia’s New President, Adama Barrow
item.media:description: President Adama Barrow of Gambia during an interview in Dakar, Senegal, on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Barrow was sworn in from Senegal when his predecessor refused to cede power. Now, preparing to take over, he discussed his vision for the nation.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Theresa May Is Grilled Over U.K. Missile Test Failure
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May spoke about Britain’s nuclear weapons program on the BBC. She would not say whether she knew about the reported failure of an unarmed missile during a test.
item.description: The prime minister refused to comment about the 2016 missile test or about reports that its failure had been covered up by her predecessor.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Hirakhand Express Train Derails in Southern India, Killing Dozens
item.media:description: Bodies were lined up along the road at the site of the derailment.
item.description: Rescue workers struggled into the morning to pull the injured and dead from the train in the latest disaster for India’s overburdened railway.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and GEETA ANAND

item.title: With French Socialists in Crisis, Manuel Valls and Benoît Hamon Head to Runoff
item.media:description: Manuel Valls, the former Socialist prime minister, at a debate at a union center in Puteaux, France, this month. France’s presidential election is being watched as a barometer of European disaffection.
item.description: The governing party is deeply unpopular and given little chance in the coming presidential election, as European voters abandon the left.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Russia Is a Terrible Ally Against Terrorism
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin in Moscow last week.
item.description: President Trump’s plan to work with Moscow to fight ISIS will alienate our allies and yield few results.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL BENJAMIN

item.title: On Campus: Discovering Feminist Students in the Middle East
item.description: My American students thought feminism was for angry man-haters. Women in Abu Dhabi were inspired by it to take risks and take charge of their lives.
item.dc:creator: DEBORAH WILLIAMS

item.title: Op-Docs: Birth Place
item.description: A day in the one of the world’s busiest maternity wards.
item.dc:creator: RAMONA S. DIAZ
